title-group.article-title: The Impact of Corporate Governance and Earnings Management on Stock Market Liquidity in a Highly Concentrated Ownership Capital Market

author-notes.corresp: Sasson Bar-Yosef, Department of Accounting, Bocconi University, Via Rontgen 1, 20136 Milan, Italy. Email: sasson.baryosef@unibocconi.it

abstract.p: We provide insights to the effects of corporate governance mechanisms and earnings management on market liquidity (measured by bid–ask spreads [B_As] and trading volume) in a setting characterized by highly concentrated noninstitutional ownership. First, we document that high noninstitutional ownership increases B_As and depresses trading volumes. Next, we show that volume of trade tends to be higher and B_A tends to be lower for firms with better corporate governance mechanisms (e.g., board independence and CEO–chairman separation) when there is high concentration of noninstitutional ownership. In contrast to prior findings, when controlling for corporate governance quality, B_As are unaffected by earnings management, while trading volume increases when earnings management is higher, presumably due to an increase in investor disagreement. Our results are robust to changes in the market trading system across the sample period.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The extant literature on the association between market liquidity, earnings management, and corporate governance suggests that bid–ask spreads (B_A) are positively correlated with earnings management levels and negatively associated with better corporate governance mechanisms, such as higher level of the board of directors’ independence and lack of CEO duality. However, to the best of our knowledge, the effect of such attributes (i.e., earnings management and corporate governance) on liquidity has been analyzed separately rather than jointly. Moreover, the empirical evidence regarding the impact of these corporate characteristics on trading volume is quite limited and the effects of earnings management and corporate governance on both elements of market liquidity (B_A as well as trading volume) in the presence of high noninstitutional ownership concentration (hereafter ownership concentration) are not yet explored in detail.

The purpose of this study is to provide empirical evidence on the joint impact of corporate governance mechanisms—including board independence and CEO duality—as well as levels of earnings management on market liquidity in a high noninstitutional ownership concentration setting. Economic interactions between different groups of market participants are fundamentally altered in a “high-ownership-concentration economy.” Studies of information asymmetry and liquidity typically assume that the main agency conflict is one between managers and shareholders, that is, Type I agency issues. However, when there exist stockholders with high ownership stake and who may possess private information, the potential conflicts turns out to be between the majority blockholder(s) and other investors, that is, the Type II agency issues may be the most significant issue. Type II agency issues may lead to significantly different relationships between the firm’s economic attributes and market liquidity, when compared with the more traditional settings where the primary agency conflict is between managers and shareholders. For example, high ownership concentration may offer the dominant shareholders easy access to superior information as well as a greater incentive to use it to trade profitably, thus inevitably affecting the liquidity of the firm shares on the market (Lev, 1988). Also, the relevance of earnings management and the effectiveness of corporate governance mechanisms may be affected in the presence of highly concentrated ownership (e.g., Prencipe & Bar-Yosef, 2011; Prencipe, Bar-Yosef, Mazzola, & Pozza, 2011). Thus, in a market setting characterized by highly concentrated ownership, the effects of corporate governance and earnings management on market liquidity is unclear.

Ownership concentration is significant in many European stock markets (as well as some other countries outside Europe) where the average level of ownership concentration tends to exceed 50% (KMU Forschung Austria, 2008). We examine the effects of corporate governance and earnings management on market liquidity within the Italian stock exchange, which typifies many other European markets with regard to high concentration of private ownership. Two surrogates for market liquidity are used: (a) the B_A and (b) the volume of trade. Our results show that in the Italian setting, better corporate governance mechanisms improve market liquidity in terms of both B_As and volume of trade, which is in line with prior reported results. In addition, ownership concentration is found to be significantly and positively correlated to B_As and negatively correlated to volume trade. However, we do not find a significant relationship between the level of earnings management (proxied by abnormal working capital accruals [AWCA]) and B_As. One possible explanation for the lack of effect of earnings management on B_As is that, in situations of high ownership concentration, market makers do not pay too much attention to financial statements but instead, focus on other indicators of information asymmetry risk such as corporate governance characteristics. A second alternative explanation is that, in the presence of high ownership concentration, market makers may not consider earnings management as a risk factor because of the monitoring directly exercised by the dominant shareholders. We also find that after controlling for corporate governance characteristics, earnings management is positively related to the volume of trade. A possible explanation for such a result is that higher levels of earnings management increase information asymmetry and, as a consequence, the disagreement among investors on the possible future outcomes, which translates into higher volume of trade.

Our empirical analysis is carried out over the period January 1999-December 2004. During the period under analysis, the Italian stock market underwent significant changes in terms of trading systems. We exploit these changes that resulted in an allocation of stocks to trading systems of greater and lesser sophistication to refine and support our findings. In particular, we find that cross-sectional differences in market liquidity between stocks that were allocated to different trading systems are consistent with our earlier findings regarding the impact of firm-level proxies for information asymmetries on market liquidity. The reminder of the article is structured as follows: The section “Literature Review and Hypothesis Development” provides a literature review and the development of the hypotheses. The “Data and Variables” section describes the sample, the Italian setting, and the variables. The section titled “Multivariate Analysis” discusses the empirical results and the last section provides some conclusions.

sec.title: Literature Review and Hypothesis Development
sec.p: The purpose of this study is to analyze the joint effect of corporate governance mechanisms—such as board independence and CEO duality—and earnings management on market liquidity when controlling for noninstitutional ownership level in a high-ownership-concentration setting.

Market liquidity is associated with width, depth, immediacy, and resiliency (Harris, 1991) and is generally considered to be beneficial to the well-functioning of capital markets.1 Prior literature on the determinants of market liquidity is quite rich. In particular, there are several studies on the effects of information asymmetry on liquidity, and on the role played by public disclosure quality (including accounting-related disclosure) in reducing information asymmetry and, consequently, in improving market liquidity (e.g., Baiman & Verrecchia, 1996; Callahan, Lee, & Yohn, 1997; Diamond & Verrecchia, 1991; Greenstein & Sami, 1994; Kim & Verrecchia, 2001; Leuz & Verrecchia, 2000; Lev, 1989; Welker, 1995). Most prior studies on the effects of disclosure quality on liquidity focus on well-defined information events, such as earnings announcements (e.g., Lee, Mucklow, & Ready, 1993) or dividend changes (e.g., Bar-Yosef & Prencipe, 2012, Graham, Koski, & Loewenstein, 2006). In this article, we intend to analyze the impact of the firm’s “general attitude” toward transparency on liquidity, hence we do not focus on specific information event. Instead, we focus on ownership concentration, other corporate governance characteristics and earnings management, which are employed as indicators of information asymmetry risk as perceived by the market on a continuous basis. To the best of our knowledge, there are no previous studies that analyze the joint effects of these determinants on market liquidity in the long run.

In the current study, liquidity is measured through two well-known measures: B_A and trading volume. Theory suggests that B_A comprised three main components (Amihud & Mendelson, 1980, 1986; Copeland & Galai, 1983; Demsetz, 1968; Easley & O’Hara, 1987; Glosten & Milgrom, 1985; Glosten & Harris, 1988; Ho & Stoll, 1981, 1983): order-processing costs, inventory holding costs, and asymmetry of information (i.e., adverse selection) costs. The last component is of the most interest to our purposes, and earlier studies on the adverse-selection component of the spread include Copeland and Galai (1983), Glosten and Milgrom (1985), Easley and O’Hara (1987), and Callahan et al. (1997). Empirical literature suggests that the adverse-selection component of the spread tends to be larger when the dealer perceives a greater likelihood of trading with better informed traders. Therefore, the adverse-selection component of the B_A reflects the degree of information asymmetry risk perceived by the dealer.2

From an accounting perspective, public disclosures may help reducing the information asymmetry problem. For example, Diamond (1985) shows that a higher level of disclosure tends to reduce investors’ incentive to acquire private information. In such an environment, liquidity providers or uninformed traders face smaller adverse-selection problems, which results in narrower B_As and greater trading activity. However, when focusing on the impact of disclosure on B_As around a specific information event, such as earnings announcements, results are mixed. For example, McNichols and Trueman (1994) and Demski and Feltham (1994) suggest that informed trading can increase prior to earnings announcements. Kim and Verrecchia (1994) show that, if investors differ in their ability to process earnings information, there will be an increase in information asymmetry immediately after the release of the earnings news. From an empirical point of view, Morse and Ushman (1983) find no significant increase in B_As around earnings announcements. Differently, Lee et al. (1993) and Yohn (1998) report results in support of an increase in B_As before and after the earnings announcements.

Other studies focus more specifically on the quality of disclosed information. For example, Greenstein and Sami (1994) show that more extensive accounting disclosure (e.g., segmented data) reduces B_As. Raman and Tripathy (1993) reports that firms that disclosed present value variables in their Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filings had lower B_As. Coller and Yohn (1998) find that the issuance of management earnings forecasts reduces information asymmetry among investors and decreases B_As in the equity market. Welker (1995) provides empirical evidence that higher levels of corporate disclosure lower the B_As. Healy, Hutton, and Palepu (1999) show that firms with sustained increases in disclosure ratings show an improvement in a number of variables, including the B_A. More recently, Heflin, Shaw, and Wild (2005) report a negative association between B_As and financial analysts’ ratings of firms’ disclosure policies. These studies imply that an improvement in the quality and the content of accounting information may lead to a reduction of information asymmetry and, consequently, of B_As.

Market liquidity is also associated with immediacy of execution, for which trading volume may be used as a surrogate. Trading volume is a measure of liquidity in that it captures the willingness of some investors to sell a firm’s shares and the willingness of others to buy. Reasonably, such willingness to transact should be inversely related to the existence of information asymmetries. Some empirical evidence supports the use of trading volume as an inverse proxy for information asymmetry (e.g., Easley. Kiefer, & O’Hara, 1996; Leuz & Verrecchia, 2000). However, compared with B_As, the relationship between information asymmetry and volume is less clear as the latter is affected by many other factors (e.g., liquidity shocks, change in risk preferences, etc.). In addition, as argued in Milgrom and Stokey (1982), volume results not so much from the information content of a disclosure but from cross-investor differences in the revision of beliefs generated by the disclosure. Perhaps, because of these complexities, only a limited number of prior studies have examined directly the association between information quality and trading volume. Among them, for example, Leuz and Verrecchia (2000) report that German firms that commit to increased levels of disclosure benefit not only from lower B_As but also from higher share turnover.

As stated above, our article focuses on corporate governance quality and earnings quality as possible indicators of information asymmetry. In the following parts, we develop our hypotheses on the impact of these two corporate traits on market liquidity.

sec.title: Corporate Governance and Market Liquidity
sec.p: Effective corporate governance encompasses controls and procedures that may provide higher degree of assurance that management acts in the interest of shareholders, thus reducing the likelihood that managers, acting in their self-interest, take actions that deviate from stockholders’ wealth maximization. Consistently, corporate governance mechanisms are expected to affect the amount and quality of information disclosed by the firm to outsiders. In particular, effective corporate governance provisions may improve firm’s transparency by mitigating management’s ability and incentive to withdraw or distort disclosure. In this respect, prior research indicates that better corporate governance mechanisms (such as board independence) tend to enhance the quality and the frequency of information released by management, thereby reducing information asymmetry. For example, Beasley (1996) suggests that the independent directors on the board reduce occurrences of financial statement fraud. Chen and Jaggi (2000) find that in Hong Kong, the total number of independent directors on corporate boards is positively associated with the comprehensiveness of financial disclosures. More recently, Patelli and Prencipe (2007) show that board of director independence is positively associated to the level of voluntary disclosure in the Italian setting. Focusing on management earnings forecasts, Ajinkya, Bhojraj, and Sengupta (2005) and Karamanou and Vafeas (2005) show that companies with more effective boards issue more frequent earnings forecasts and that these forecasts are more accurate.

Based on the above, one may expect that better corporate governance increases market liquidity by reducing the information asymmetry component of B_As. However, scant studies have directly linked the corporate governance quality to the B_As. Kanagaretnam, Lobo, and Whalen (2007) indicate that changes in B_As at the time of earnings announcements are significantly negatively related to board independence, board activity, and the percentage stock holdings of directors and officers. Chung, Elder, and Kim (2010) find that firms with better corporate governance have narrower spreads, higher market quality index, smaller price impact of trades, and lower probability of information-based trading. Levesque, Libby, Mathieu, and Robb (2010) indicate that the market attributes a lower level of information asymmetry to firms with a larger proportion of outside directors on the board.

While prior evidence on markets characterized by diffused ownership generally supports the hypothesis that better corporate governance reduces B_As, there is no evidence on the extent (if at all) of the impact on such relationship in a market setting characterized by highly noninstitutional ownership concentration. Prior literature suggests that the presence of blockholders reduces market liquidity, as the market makers and investors tend to perceive a higher risk of information asymmetry (Bhide, 1993; Lev, 1988). For example, Heflin and Shaw (2000) find that firms with greater blockholder ownership, either by managers or external entities, have larger quoted spreads, effective spreads, adverse-selection spread components, and smaller quoted depths. This is because blockholders are believed to have access to private, value-relevant information via their roles as monitors of firms’ operations, which increases perceived information asymmetry by outsiders, giving rise to Type II agency issue. In the presence of significant blockholders, effective corporate governance (especially board independence) mechanisms may become more important, as the perceived risk of information asymmetry tends to increase. However, when ownership concentration is highly significant and such owners are able to affect corporate decisions and policies and/or appoint the CEO and/or the board members, the effectiveness of corporate governance mechanisms becomes less obvious (Prencipe & Bar-Yosef, 2011). Market makers, who set the B_As, being aware of the consequences of such association between owners and management and its possible impact on reporting policies, may forgo corporate governance quality indicators. Because of the lack of a clear direction in our expectation, our hypothesis will be formulated in the null form:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1.a: Corporate governance quality is not associated with B_As in a highly noninstitutional ownership concentration setting.

sec.p: Our expectation about the impact of corporate governance on trading volume is based on arguments similar to those discussed for the B_As. To the extent that volume is affected by the information asymmetry risk perceived by the investors, and to the extent that investors look at good corporate governance quality as an indicator of the risk to trade against better informed traders, it is reasonable to expect a positive relationship between corporate governance quality and trading volume. However, in a setting characterized by highly concentrated ownership, this relationship might change. On one hand, good corporate governance (especially in terms of board independence) may become crucial to reduce the perceived risk of information asymmetry arising from the fact that blockholders may have privileged access to information compared with outside investors. On the other hand, the influence exercised by controlling shareholders on corporate decisions related to CEO and/or to board members may reduce the perceived effectiveness of corporate governance mechanisms. Therefore, also in relation to the volume, we formulate our expectation in the null form:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1.b: Corporate governance quality is not associated with trading volume in a highly noninstitutional ownership concentration setting.

sec.p: In our empirical analysis, we focus on two main corporate governance traits, namely, the level of board independence and CEO duality. Higher board independence is generally associated with a better corporate governance quality. To the contrary, CEO duality—that is, when the same individual acts as CEO as well as the board chairman—reduces corporate governance quality as it tends to decrease the monitoring ability of the board (e.g., Fama & Jensen, 1983; Jensen, 1993; Kong-Hee & Buchanan, 2008; Lee, Rosenstein, Rangan, & Davidson, 1992; Worrell, Nemec, & Davidson, 1997). We will elaborate more on these two proxies in the section “Corporate Governance Proxies.”

sec.title: Earnings Management and Market Liquidity
sec.p: Earnings quality is another source of information asymmetry that may affect market liquidity. In this study, we use the level of earnings management as a proxy for earnings quality. The idea is that higher levels of earnings management increase the information asymmetry between insiders and outsiders, as it reduces the reliability of reported earnings and increases the uncertainty for investors about future cash flows. Therefore, earnings management may have potentially negative effects in terms of liquidity.

There is very limited prior evidence on the relationship between earnings management and B_As. For example, using a different perspective, Richardson (2000) suggests that there is a systematic relationship between the degree of information asymmetry as measured by the B_A and the level of earnings management. Bhattacharya, Desai, and Venkataraman (2012) document that poor earnings quality is associated with higher B_As (both in general and around earnings announcements). However, the effect of earnings management on B_As is not so obvious. The analysis of earnings management policies requires time and technical expertise. Prior literature suggests that the information asymmetry risk perceived by specialists is different from the one perceived by analysts and investors. Indeed, specialists are not thought to do any fundamental analysis such as analyzing the annual reports. They rather aim at maximizing the turnover of their capital (Kim & Verrecchia, 1994). Market makers, therefore, are not expected to pay too much attention to the earnings quality profile of the firm, but rather on more easily identifiable indicators of the risk of trading with better informed investors (such as corporate governance mechanisms). In addition, prior empirical literature shows that good corporate governance mechanisms tend to reduce earnings management (e.g., Beasley, 1996; Dechow, Sloan, & Sweeny, 1996; Klein, 2002). This implies that—after controlling for corporate governance quality—there might not be much room for earnings management as a determinant of market liquidity.3

Moreover, when ownership is highly concentrated, managers are better monitored by blockholders. This might reduce the incentives for the former to implement earnings management policies, as suggested by recent empirical literature (e.g., Cascino, Pugliese, Mussolino, & Sansone, 2010; Prencipe et al., 2011; Wang, 2006). In such a setting, market participants may not price earnings management as they do for widely held firms.
Based on the arguments discussed above, we formulate the following hypothesis in the null form:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2.a: Earnings management is not associated with B_As in a highly noninstitutional ownership concentration setting.

sec.p: Different from the case of B_As—where market makers are expected to pay little attention to corporate financial reports—the role played by earnings management in the investors’ trading decisions is potentially more relevant. Indeed, investors may trade on stocks following reports and recommendations of financial analysts. Financial analysts are typically experts who carefully analyze corporate financial reports, which are affected by earnings management policies. To the extent that financial analysts consider earnings management as an indicator of information asymmetry risk on top of and beyond corporate governance characteristics, there will be an (indirect) negative association between the level of earnings management and trade volume. However, such an association is not univocal. By increasing the uncertainty for investors about the future cash flows of the firm, earnings management is potentially able to increase the disagreement among investors by causing a differential belief revision following the disclosure of accounting news by the firm (e.g., Barron, 1995; Karpoff, 1986). For example, a recent empirical work suggests that a lower level of reporting conservatism (which may be considered a proxy for earnings quality) tends to increase the investor disagreement following earnings announcement (D’Augusta, Bar-Yosef, & Prencipe, 2012). Based on this line of reasoning, earnings management may translate into a higher (rather than lower) trading volume. Again, due to the unclear direction in the association between earnings management and trading volume, our hypothesis is formulated in the null form as follows:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2.b: Earnings management is not associated with trading volume in a highly noninstitutional ownership concentration setting.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: Our sample is composed of 130 nonfinancial Italian companies listed on the Milan Stock Exchange (Borsa Italiana) during the 6-year period from 1999 to 2004.

The relatively small sample size is mainly due to the limited size of the Italian stock market. Also, lack of historical ownership data from Consob (the Italian security exchange supervisory authority) provides data only from 1999.4 The post-2004 period has been excluded to avoid accounting data discontinuity due to the introduction of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) regulations in 2005.

The data were collected from a variety of sources: Stock market (trade) data were collected from Reuters (on the FactSet platform). Ownership composition data were collected from Consob online database. Number of shares outstanding were collected from FactSet. Board of directors’ composition and CEO duality were collected manually from the corporate governance reports, and financial accounting data were retrieved from the Analisi Informatizzata Delle Aziende (AIDA) database.

Only observations with complete relevant financial, ownership, and market data were included in the sample. Data were winsorized for the extreme 1% observations. The final sample consists of 5,282 firm-month observations, corresponding to 130 unique firms.

sec.title: The Structure of the Italian Stock Market
sec.p: For a better understanding of the potential implications of our analysis, it may be useful to briefly describe some of the features of the Italian stock market.

The Italian stock exchange (i.e., Borsa Italiana) is an order-driven market. As of 1991, equity orders executions are made by an electronic trading system (Mercato Telematico Azionario [MTA]) which enables brokers to trade in securities in real-time from computer terminals directly linked to Borsa Italiana. Furthermore, like most other European exchanges (i.e., Deutsche Börse, London Stock Exchange, Euronext, etc.), Borsa Italiana operates under a segmented market structure. In April 2001, the two old categories of shares, that is, liquid and less liquid stocks, were reorganized under three new segments (i.e., Blue Chip, STAR, and Standard) primarily based on market capitalization. Each of these segments applies a slightly different trading mechanism within the MTA.5

The Blue Chip segment includes companies with a market capitalization larger than €1,000 million. Blue Chip stocks are traded on a continuous auction basis using an open limit order book. The STAR segment (i.e., Segmento Titoli ad Alti Requisiti) is composed of midcap companies (market capitalization between €40 million and €1,000 million) which, on a voluntary basis, have decided to apply higher standards of transparency, corporate governance, and liquidity (of at least 35% of free-float). This segment is characterized by a hybrid trading system, that is, trades can be either executed by liquidity providers (i.e., specialists) who disseminate quotes to the market and trade on own account (buying or selling out of own inventory) or post orders on the electronic order book which is visible to other traders. The third segment is the Standard segment (or Segmento Ordinario) which is composed of midcap stocks with standard requirements (i.e., market capitalization between €40 million and €1,000 million). These stocks are traded in a series of call auctions throughout the trading day.

As of 2004, in addition to the MTA and its three primary segments,6 there has been also the Mercato Expandi, which is a segment that groups small and midsized companies with lower documentation requirements than the rest of the market.7 Expandi allows trading in stocks with a free-float of 10% and whose shares are offered only to institutional investors.

sec.title: Liquidity Proxies
sec.p: As mentioned earlier, in the current study we use two proxies for liquidity: B_A and trading volume.

sec.title: B_A
sec.p: The B_A is defined as the difference between the price at which the market maker (the liquidity provider) or investors in general buy a security (bid price) and the price at which the market maker or investors are willing to sell the security (ask/offer price). The B_A is positive. The difference between the bid and ask prices varies depending on the cost incurred by the liquidity provider to hold the stock, and the perception of the risk of trading with the better informed investors (Amihud & Mendelson, 1986; Copeland & Galai, 1983; Stoll, 1989).

In an order-driven setting, like Borsa Italiana, such relationship will turn to be less explicit, due to the absence of stand-alone market-making quotes, but still reflects the overall information gap among traders. In an order-driven market structure, B_A quotes are supplied through public limit orders that are input into and matched by a fully automated computerized system. It has been shown (Cohen, Maier, Schwartz, & Whitcomb, 1981) that order-driven auction markets give rise to positive B_As, and that the free entry and exit of informal market makers is able to sustain a viable securities market. In addition, adverse-selection costs generate positive B_As (Glosten, 1994) and, given the fact that market participants are willing to pay for price certainty, order-driven market-making is similar to a quote-driven, and the spread represents the expected compensation for the cost of supplying intermediacy. Prior research suggests that informed trading translates into wider B_As (e.g., Copeland & Galai, 1983; Glosten & Milgrom, 1985; Ho & Stoll, 1983). Wider B_As usually imply greater information asymmetry between informed and uninformed investors and, at the same time, create higher cost of capital for firms making it costlier to buy and sell shares on the market (e.g., Amihud & Mendelson, 1986).

sec.title: Volume
sec.p: Trading volume is the other indicator of liquidity applied in this study. One of the conditions that drives stock liquidity is the required orders execution time for a given stock. This time is affected by the stock traded volume (e.g., Bar-Yosef & Prencipe, 2012; Ready, 1999): A higher volume implies a higher probability of order execution. Standing by itself, trading volume provides no indication on how the trades affect the price of the stock. Trades take place when there are diverse opinion on the intrinsic value of the stock or when the seller requires immediate cash (liquidity traders). Optimal trading strategies are offered to minimize trading costs (involving adverse price impacts; see, for example, Huberman & Stanzl, 2005).

sec.title: Earnings Management Proxy
sec.p: The extant literature suggests several means of estimating earnings management, for example, the Jones (1991) model or the “modified Jones” model (Dechow, Sloan, & Sweeny, 1995; Kothari, Leone, & Wasley, 2005). However, these models do not produce reliable estimates for small number of observations (Peek, Meuwissen, Moers, & Vanstraelen, in press; Wysocki, 2004), a common feature of several European capital markets. An alternative earnings management proxy was offered by DeFond and Park (2001). DeFond and Park suggest applying the AWCA to estimate the extent of earnings management. AWCA is defined as the difference between realized working capital and the expected working capital required to sustain current sales level.

Using AWCA as an earnings management proxy has two advantages. First, it can be applied even if we have a limited number of observations per industry/year. Second, it proved to be a good proxy for the earnings management as perceived by the investors (DeFond & Park, 2001), therefore it is particularly suitable to our purposes.

sec.title: Corporate Governance Proxies
sec.p: Corporate governance quality may influence investors’ perception of the firm’s transparency and consequently affect their evaluations. To evaluate the potential impact of corporate governance quality on the perception of asymmetric information by capital market participants, two main indicators are applied.

The first indicator is the degree of board independence, estimated as the ratio of independent directors to total board members. An independent director is defined according to the “independence criteria” explicitly stated in the Corporate Governance Code (Borsa Italiana, 1999, pp. 35-36):
An adequate number of nonexecutive directors shall be independent, in the sense that they do not maintain, nor have recently maintained, directly or indirectly, any business relationships with the issuer or persons linked to the issuer, of such a significance as to influence their autonomous judgment. (pp. 35-36)

Such an autonomous judgment is generally expected to mitigate information asymmetry and, consequently, reduce adverse-selection problems. Furthermore, board independence potentially leads to better monitoring and may enhance the quality of financial reports. Also, independent directors may be perceived by investors as a particularly important factor in restraining managerial opportunism, thus mitigating moral hazard problems. Thus, a higher degree of board independence is expected to induce lower perceived asymmetry of information.

The second indicator of corporate governance quality applied in the current study is CEO duality, that is, when the firm’s CEO serves also as the chairman of the board of directors. CEO duality decreases board independence and may lead to a higher perceived asymmetry of information. Put differently, CEO duality may be perceived by capital market participants as an indication of a weaker corporate governance system, with potential increase in managerial opportunism and higher asymmetry of information. CEO duality was measured through a dummy variable assuming value 1 for duality, 0 otherwise.
Information on board composition and CEO duality was hand-collected from firms’ annual corporate governance reports.

While the literature generally supports the idea that board independence and the lack of CEO duality are associated to a better corporate governance (e.g., Fama & Jensen, 1983; Jensen, 1993; Kong-Hee & Buchanan, 2008; Lee et al., 1992; Worrell et al., 1997), the effectiveness of such mechanisms in the presence of highly concentrated ownership is not so obvious. In fact, ownership structure may be considered another corporate governance trait. Higher ownership concentration opens the door to agency problems between dominant and minority shareholders (Type II agency issues) and gives the former privileged access to inside information, which may negatively affect market liquidity. In economic settings like the Italian and some other European economies, where there exists a high ownership concentration, market participants may associate to such a corporate governance trait a higher risk of information asymmetry, resulting in lower liquidity.9 In addition, as discussed above, high ownership concentration may reduce the effectiveness of other corporate governance mechanisms, such as board independence and lack of CEO duality, due to the strong influence exercised on both management and board members by the influential shareholders. Therefore, in settings like the Italian, it is opportune to introduce ownership concentration as an additional corporate governance proxy.
Ownership concentration is measured as the aggregate percentage of shares held by shareholders owning at least 2% of the ordinary share capital.

sec.title: Control Variables
sec.p: An appropriate test of our hypotheses requires controlling for other possible variables that might affect market liquidity.

Stock return and stock return volatility are shown to affect market liquidity (e.g., Amihud & Mendelson, 1986, 1989; Bhattacharya et al., 2012). It is also argued that financial leverage may be associated with market liquidity (e.g., Amihud & Mendelson, 2012; Lang & Lundholm, 1993). Market liquidity may also be affected by the profitability of the company as more profitable companies may attract more investors and thus increasing liquidity. Hence, Return on Assets (ROA) is taken as a profitability measure. It has also been reported that the analysts following affects liquidity (McNichols & O’Brien, 1997), therefore the number of analysts who follow the firm is included as an additional control variable. Finally, the total number of shares outstanding affects trading and thus is controlled for.

sec.p: Table 2 shows that the average size (Total Assets) of firms in the sample is €3.7 billion with an average ROA of 4.4%. The average daily B_A is about 5.9 cents or B_A (%) of 1% of the security’s price (with median values of 2.9 cents and 0.86%, respectively). Average trading volume is about 1.26 million shares (median of 0.058 million). The monthly market return mean is −0.52% (median +0.6%) and an average volatility of 1.64%. Note that noninstitutional owners are the most dominant category of investors with an average stake above 58% of the total equity capital.10 The mean ratio of independent directors is 28% and in almost 32% of the sample firms, there is CEO duality, that is, the CEO also serves as a chairman of the board of directors. The mean AWCA is −0.05% of total assets (median of −0.18%). On the average, about six analysts follow each sampled firm (ranging from 0 to 39) and the average financial leverage is 59%. Also, note that the trading segments are distributed as follows: 26% of the sampled firms belong to the Blue Chip segment, 33% to the STAR, and 41% to the Standard segment.

Table 3 provides the Spearman’s rank correlation matrix for the main variables. The B_A and the trading volume (Volume) variables are negatively correlated (−0.46), consistent with prior microstructure literature (e.g., Bar-Yosef & Prencipe, 2012; Wang & Yhu, 2000). It is also interesting to note the high correlation of the number of analysts (Analysts) with B_A, Volume, and Total Assets: −0.41, 0.65, and 0.42, respectively. B_A is negatively correlated with ROA (−0.14). The correlations of earnings management (AWCA) with B_A and Volume are fairly low (.06 and −.05, respectively), suggesting that the impact of earnings management on market liquidity is not clear. Instead, the correlations between B_A and corporate governance proxies indicate that better quality corporate governance tends to increase liquidity. Indeed, the level of board independence (Indep) and CEO duality (Dual) show a correlation with B_A of −0.18 and 0.09, respectively, and a correlation with Volume of 0.14 and −0.21, respectively. Interestingly, and consistently with expectations, ownership concentration (Ownership) is positively correlated with B_A (0.17) and negatively correlated with Volume (−0.33), confirming that higher ownership concentration tends to reduce liquidity.

sec.title: Corporate Governance and Liquidity
sec.p: To test the hypotheses related to corporate governance and liquidity, we utilize the following two regression models:

where i and t represent the stock i and the month t. Fixed effects are for industries and years, and ϵit stands for the regression error. Our two main test variables are Indep—which designates board independence—and Dual—which designates CEO duality. All other variables are defined in Table 1.

The estimation results for the heteroscedastic robust standard errors regression models are presented in Table 4. The two regression models are significant with R2 = .39 and .88 for the B_A and Volume models, respectively.11 First, one may note that the coefficient of Volume and B_A in these regression models are negative and significant, in line with the extant microstructure empirical research. The variable Indep is weakly significant in the B_A regression (−.08, t value of −1.73) with a negative sign and—although not significant—has a positive coefficient in the Volume regression (0.04, t value of 0.76). The variable Dual is significantly and positively correlated to the B_A (0.06 with t value of 2.84) and negatively correlated to Volume (−.14 with a t value of −5.92). Taken together, such results move in the direction that a more effective corporate governance tends to improve both dimensions of liquidity, notwithstanding the presence of high ownership concentration which might reduce the effectiveness of board independence mechanisms. Interestingly, and in line with expectations, the signs of the coefficients for ownership concentration (Ownership) in the two models are indicating that the higher the ownership concentration, the lower the liquidity. The ownership concentration coefficient in the B_A model is positive and significant (0.13 and t value of 2.16), indicating that higher ownership concentration is associated with higher B_As. As expected, the market makers tend to consider this element as a risk factor and price it accordingly. The same coefficient in the volume model is negative and significant (−1.71 and t value of −19.24). This may imply that investors tend to trade less in stocks of higher concentrated ownership because of higher perceived risk of information asymmetry. Therefore, high ownership concentration is associated with lower market liquidity.12

sec.p: Regarding the control variables, the number of analysts (Analysts), as expected, is negatively associated with the B_As (coefficient of −0.11 with t value of −12.59) and positively associated with trading volume (coefficient of 0.09 with t value of 6.61). These results are of no surprise if one considers that analysts provide recommendations that are based on in-depth analyses of the stocks, thus potentially reducing the information asymmetry.13 Financial leverage (Lev) tends to be positively associated with B_As as suggested by Amihud and Mendelson (2012), and so is the market return volatility (Volat), while market returns tend to have an opposite effect on the spreads (Amihud, 2002). The Volume is positively associated with both market returns and market return volatility. Finally, note that in the Volume model, we also control for the number of shares outstanding (Shares).14 As expected, this is positively correlated to the trading volume. Thus, based on these results, we can reject the Null Hypotheses 1.a and 1.b.

sec.p: To analyze the impact of earnings management on our measures of liquidity, the following models have been estimated:

Again, as in Table 4 above, B_A and Volume confirm to be negatively and significantly correlated in the two models. Our main test variable AWCA (i.e., our earnings management proxy) has an insignificant coefficient in the B_A regression, while the coefficient in the volume regression is positive and significant (0.43, with t value 2.70). Such results indicate that—while market makers do not pay close attention to earnings management, consistently with the hypothesis—the trading volume increases when earnings management is higher, suggesting that the latter tends to increase investor disagreement.

sec.title: The Joint Effect of Corporate Governance and Earnings Management on Liquidity
sec.p: After we have considered the separate effects of corporate governance and earnings management, we would like to examine the joint effects of these determinants on market liquidity. Considering the joint effect of corporate governance and earnings management is a necessary step for a suitable test of the hypotheses because—as suggested by prior studies—corporate governance quality is negatively associated to earnings management. It is therefore interesting to examine the extent (if at all) to which each determinant affects liquidity once controlling for the other. Therefore, we run the following regression models:

sec.p: The regression models are significant with adjusted R2 of .39 and .89 for the B_A and the volume models, respectively. The impact of the corporate governance variables on market liquidity is similar and consistent with those reported in Table 4. While ownership concentration confirms to be strongly and negatively affecting market liquidity both in terms of B_As and in terms of trading volume, the impact of board independence is less clear. Indeed, the coefficient of Indep in the B_A model is negative but only marginally significant (−.08, with t value of −1.73), while it is insignificant in the volume model. Such results suggest that a higher proportion of independent directors on the corporate board does not have strong effects on market liquidity in a setting characterized by high ownership concentration. A possible explanation for this is that market operators are aware of the fact that the strong influence exercised by blockholders may reduce actual independence of board members, consistent with prior literature (Prencipe & Bar-Yosef, 2011). However, the coefficients of CEO duality suggest that this indicator of corporate governance quality is considered more relevant by market makers and traders. CEO duality reduces liquidity, that is, is positively correlated with B_As and negatively associated with volume. Also, the impact of the earnings management on market liquidity is similar to that reported in Table 5. The coefficient of AWCA on the B_A is insignificant, suggesting that market makers focus more on corporate governance indicators rather than on in-depth analysis of financial reports. Instead, the coefficient of AWCA in the volume equation is positive and significant (0.60 and t value of 3.79), suggesting an increase in investor disagreement when earnings management impact is higher.

sec.title: Robustness Test: The Different Trading Systems
sec.p: As stated in the “The Structure of the Italian Stock Market” section, the trading system of the Milan Stock Exchange (MTA) was changed in April 2001: The two old trading categories (liquid and less liquid stocks) were reorganized into three new trading segments (Blue Chip, STAR, and Standard), which are primarily based on market capitalization and level of transparency. These segmented “trading floors” operate under a slightly different trading mechanism within the MTA. For example, some stocks that were traded under an auction-only market are traded, after the new trading classification, in a specialist market.

sec.p: The results indicate that the risk premium for asymmetry of information is lower with the more transparent firms, that is, the companies belonging to the segments Star in the Blue Chip segment. Indeed, in the B_A model, the coefficient of the ChangeStar is negative and significant (0.23 with t value of 6.70), and that in the trading volume regression is significantly negative (−0.619 with t value of −14.74). This might be explained by the larger size in terms of market capitalization of the companies in the Blue Chip segment compared with the Star companies. The different size and lower transparency are probably the driver of the sign of the coefficients related to the variable ChangeStd. Companies in the Standard segments are smaller and perhaps less transparent than those listed in the Blue Chip segment, bearing the consequences of higher B_A and lower volume for the former compared with the latter.

Apparently, controlling for trading segments does not affect our main findings. It is worth noticing that—when controlling for the trading segments—the variable Indep loses its significance also in the B_A regression. Most likely, its effect has been absorbed by the characteristics of the three segments as these segments designate companies of different qualities of corporate governance structure, including better board independence.

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: The purpose of this article is to provide additional insights regarding the joint effects of corporate governance mechanisms and earnings management on market liquidity (proxied by B_As and trading volume) in a market setting characterized by highly concentrated noninstitutional ownership. While prior literature generally suggests that B_As are positively correlated with earnings management levels and negatively associated with better corporate governance mechanisms, such corporate attributes have not been analyzed jointly. Moreover, the empirical evidence regarding the impact of these corporate characteristics on trading volume is rather limited. This study provides empirical evidence on the joint impact of corporate governance mechanisms and earnings management on market liquidity in a setting of high noninstitutional ownership concentration. High ownership concentration alters both the nature and the effects of asymmetric information on market liquidity. The presence of a dominant shareholder may increase the value of strong corporate governance mechanisms or, alternatively, make them less effective. Analogously, the market may react more sharply to earnings management because of the possibility that an owner-director is likely to have private information, or ignore it given that the stock already incorporates a discount related to the strategic informational advantage of a dominant shareholder. Thus, in market settings characterized by highly concentrated ownership, the effects of corporate governance and earnings management on market liquidity, either individually or jointly, cannot be characterized from theory and have to be examined using empirical methods These results are of interest for many European (and some non-European) markets where noninstitutional ownership concentration is significant.

Our results show that, in a setting characterized by high ownership concentration and after controlling for its level, better corporate governance mechanisms tend to improve market liquidity in terms of both B_As and volume of trade, which confirms that the market believes that such indicators help to evaluate the risk of information asymmetry. In addition, ownership concentration is found to be significantly and positively correlated to B_As and negatively correlated to volume of trade. However, we do not find a significant relationship between the level of earnings management (proxied by AWCA) and B_As. We suggest that: first, market makers do not rely on financial statements and fundamental analysis. Instead, they are more focused on other indicators of information asymmetry risk such as corporate governance characteristics. Alternatively, in the presence of high ownership concentration, market makers may not consider earnings management as a risk factor because of the monitoring directly exercised on managers by the dominant shareholders. Second, we find that—when controlling for corporate governance characteristics—earnings management is positively related to the trading volume. A possible explanation for such results is that higher levels of earnings management increase information asymmetry and—as a consequence—the disagreement among investors on the possible future outcome of an investment, which translates into higher volume of trade. Last, we examine the effects of changes in the trading system that split stocks across different types of exchanges. The results are robust for stocks traded under different institutional structures suggesting that our findings are more generally applicable to other markets with high noninstitutional ownership.
